entry.title: Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992) (4)
entry.content:
Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992) (4)20130413
I played today for about three hours and beat the game. I found
the game to continue to be very adorable. The final area wasn't
particularly hard, but it was very fun to get the Phoenix shot
upgrade.

Overall, I found the game to be very fun and cute. I would
definitely recommend it for the good mechanics and the nice
story. The story and mechanics, however, don't feel good enough to
me to warrant many replays, so I don't think I will play it
again. But I definitely will think of it fondly.

I'm excited to see what connections future Quintet games will have
to this world.

Total time: 7:59
  • Video Games
  • Soul Blazer
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992) (2)
entry.content:
Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992) (2)20130411
I played for about two hours today and had a very good time. I
got to the third area and did almost everything I could at this
point in the earlier areas. Although I know that there will be
more to do once I can damage metal enemies.

The game is very cute and there's a lot more connections and
similarities to Actraiser. It's like you're a different avatar of
"The Master". You move around to different towns to restore. There
was even a kid named Teddy! (That's the name of a kid from
Bloodpool in Actraiser.) I really enjoyed the second area, because
it was a town of animals. In both of the first two areas, you also
go into the dreams of a plant :) It was neat too when an old man
says he's was lonely when his wife died but then got a goat to
take care of; when you talk to the goat, it says it's the wife
reincarnated and even though she can't talk to her husband, she's
glad to be around him. Cute.

The combat is getting a little more complex as there are more
enemies that shoot projectiles, etc. But it's not incredibly
complicated, because the controls are so stiff and tile-based.

Total time: 2:39
  • Video Games
  • Soul Blazer
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Joe & Mac (SNES, 1991)
entry.content:
Game: Joe & Mac (SNES, 1991)20130410
I played this for the first two levels. I remember seeing this
game in Nintendo Power and being incredibly impressed by the
visuals. Now that I am older and playing it, it feels like the
visuals are the main reason for this game being terrible. The
sprites are too big for the action and the hit boxes are real
bad. Amazingly, it is a 2D platformer with camera problems. When
you die, if you move to the right, then the screen doesn't scroll
with your ghost. This made it so I couldn't see the next platform,
I had to go backwards then right again to get it to
scroll. There's really nothing special about this game at all.

Total time: 0:06
  • Video Games
  • Joe & Mac
  • SNES
  • 1991

entry.title: Game: Romancing SaGa (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Romancing SaGa (SNES, 1992)20130410
I played this for a bit. Although my Japanese is good enough to
understand all the words on the interface, I couldn't get anything
out of the story. The mechanics of the game are very confusing
(like most Saga games I've played) and not particularly appealing.

The row system is a little neat and there's clearly a lot of
freedom. The ability to see the hordes of monsters on the screen
is interesting. But... I won't play it.

Total time: 0:11
  • Video Games
  • Romancing SaGa
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992)20130410
I played this for about forty minutes and had a really good
time. I've played Illusion of Gaia before and it's a lot like
it. It's a traditional action RPG, but there are something neat
things about it.

In the story/structure, it is very similar to Quintet's Actraiser
(which I just played), in that as you fight monsters, you
"restore" lost parts of the towns and unlock people who were
captive and now tell you about their lives. I've enjoyed the
reveals so far. My favorite was a goat that, after giving you a
hint, said, "I have other things to attend to now", and then
walked off.

In the battle mechanics, it's also like Actraiser in that there
are monster spawn points that release one monster after
another. The difference, though, is that here you just have to
kill a certain number and then the spawn point is sealed. Since
you know where they are going to spawn, there's a temptation to
sit on top of it and spam the attack, but they thought of that and
the enemies are invulnerable when they first appear, but they can
still hurt you. Instead, you have to stand a little bit of a way
back and spam the attack button. =) I haven't gotten to a place
where the combat is tricky, but it does feel good, and that counts
for a lot.

I'll definitely keep playing this.

Total time: 0:43
  • Video Games
  • Soul Blazer
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Super Adventure Island (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Super Adventure Island (SNES, 1992)20130410
I have a lot of memories of playing the original Adventure Island
on the NES. I love the Rogue-like "hunger" system. It's very
unique.

This game was incredibly similar to those games, although with a
lot more of a slow pace. In the NES game, you seem to almost
always have a skateboard, so it's more like a modern "runner" in
that you just control the jumping (and shooting.) I found this one
to be much more deliberate and that it emphasized using the
weapons against the enemies more, whereas that seemed to be more
of a bonus in the earlier game.

Like a lot of early SNES games I've been playing, I feel like
they got drunk on giant sprites and didn't polish the tightness
and feel of the game enough. I'm excited about the next game
though, because I hear it is drastically different.

Total time: 0:16
  • Video Games
  • Super Adventure Island
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Super Castlevania 4 (SNES, 1991) (2)
entry.content:
Game: Super Castlevania 4 (SNES, 1991) (2)20130410
I played this for about thirty minutes. I got to 3-3 on my first
continue. 

This game is a lot worse than the NES Castlevania games and it is
nowhere close to Dracula X. I think the biggest problem is the
really stiff transitions between states. You can very clear see
the game stutter when you jump, start swinging, get on a ladder,
etc. Unlike the first game, where the deliberateness of the game
seems to be a purposeful feature... in this game it seems like a
bad mistake.

In addition, I agree with the Sequelitis estimation of the
negative aspects of the eight-way whip: the combat sequences are
simply easy. I barely got hit a single time and the only times I
died, it was because of falling during platforming (primarily
during swinging segments.)

Total time: 0:54
  • Video Games
  • Super Castlevania 4
  • SNES
  • 1991

entry.title: Game: Super Ghouls ‘N Ghosts (SNES, 1991)
entry.content:
Game: Super Ghouls ‘N Ghosts (SNES, 1991)20130410
I played this for about ten minutes. I couldn't make it past the
second hill in the first level after using all ten lives. It was
totally brutal.

This game puts Castlevania to shame in its clunkiness. I can
possibly see how the strange jumping system would be interesting,
but in my little experience... it was just unbearable.

Total time: 0:11

  • Super Ghouls ‘N Ghosts
  • SNES
  • 1991

entry.title: Game: Super Ninja Boy (SNES, 1991)
entry.content:
Game: Super Ninja Boy (SNES, 1991)20130410
I'd heard a lot about this game in recent years. I played it for a
while and got to level 4. It's pretty brilliant and unique.

It's basically an "Action RPG", but whereas games like Zelda II
and Kingdom Hearts add RPG mechanics to a popular action genre,
Super Ninja Boy takes a normal RPG structure---world map, random
battles, etc---but then puts action mechanics into the random
battles. I get the impression that increasing levels would make a
difference with the combat, but I never noticed it.

This sounds great, and it is, but the action mechanics are just
terrible. It is so sluggish. It almost seems like it is trying to
be in slow motion when you jump. It's kind of embarrassing
actually.

The text and story is ridiculous too. The opening cinematic with
"Emperor Chin of Chinaland". Ouch.

Total time: 0:12
  • Video Games
  • Super Ninja Boy
  • SNES
  • 1991

entry.title: Game: Super Tennis (SNES, 1991)
entry.content:
Game: Super Tennis (SNES, 1991)20130410
I played this game for about six minutes. In the first two
minutes, I thought to myself, "Wow, this is really fun. It's like
Pong, but with just barely a bit more where you have to press a
button to hit the ball back." But then quickly I got in a huge
stretch of Fault, Double Fault, and couldn't even deliver the
ball to the other side. I don't think I got any hits in after
that. It was pretty miserable and I gave up.

Total time: 0:06

  • Super Tennis
  • SNES
  • 1991

entry.title: Movie: Life of Pi, starring Suraj Sharma (2012)
entry.content:
Movie: Life of Pi, starring Suraj Sharma (2012)20130410
This was an interesting movie. My wife had read the book and given
me a run down of it, so I knew the story. I thought it was very
neat, although a bit of religious language was really shallow and
embarrassing. I like the carnivorous island part the most.

entry.title: Game: Final Fantasy 2 (US) (SNES, 1991) (5)
entry.content:
Game: Final Fantasy 2 (US) (SNES, 1991) (5)20130409
Today I played for a little more than three hours and finished the
game. I got everything in the game and got to the ending. The
ending is so moving... I nearly cried as the intro music played
again as all the characters came back. The final moments are crazy
too because there is yet another "true enemy" reveal.

Despite fighting through the lunar underground pretty easily and
getting every item in the game /and/ having full health... I was
destroyed by Zeromus instantly after just about two rounds.

I really dislike it when a JRPG doesn't give you a reason to
grind. When I grind to gather money to get more items, that's
fine, because I'm earning the money and I get the levels at the
same time. When you have to get into random battles as you are
going through a maze and gathering treasure chests, it's
fine. But if I can make it to the boss and get all the items, I
should have grinded enough to do it.

I couldn't bring myself to grind to defeat Zeromus. I looked into
using a Game Genie code to move it along faster, but they didn't
work. So I'm calling it done.

Final Fantasy 2 is amazing.

Game 3: 19:06
Total time: 79:06
  • Video Games
  • Final Fantasy 2 (US)
  • SNES
  • 1991

entry.title: Game: Final Fantasy 2 (US) (SNES, 1991) (4)
entry.content:
Game: Final Fantasy 2 (US) (SNES, 1991) (4)20130408
Today I played for about three hours. I made it past the moon and
into the Giant of Babil. This game is so great in its huge
scope... you even go to the moon! I'm finding the random battles
to be a little brutal, because they happen a lot more than I
expect... sometimes one after another.

I still need to get some stuff at the Cave of Monsters, like
equipment, etc, but I'm basically done with the non-Odin/Bahamut
side quests.

entry.title: Game: Final Fantasy 2 (US) (SNES, 1991) (3)
entry.content:
Game: Final Fantasy 2 (US) (SNES, 1991) (3)20130407
I played for a long time today because we were sitting around
listening to the radio the majority of the day. I got through the
fight with Rubicant, which is basically the start of the last
third of the game. This game's cast is so much fun, even though
they are pretty shallow generally. There are some little moments
of depth though... like with Rydia and the fire spell. I think it
is comical how many characters nobly sacrifice themselves for the
group (and how quickly they do it too!) So funny.

Game 3: 12:39

entry.title: Game: ActRaiser (SNES, 1990) (2)
entry.content:
Game: ActRaiser (SNES, 1990) (2)20130406
I beat the game this morning in about two hours. The final boss
rush was really lazy and the last boss fight was really
unfair. Prior to going into the last stage, I used earthquake on
most of the towns so that they could be rebuilt with better
structures. That enabled me to get up two more levels so I would
hit the max level and have the strength to beat it.

The ending, as you go through each town again, is very cute and
the very last moment when they talk about how people don't worship
God after they become advanced is very interesting.

Overall, I found the game to fun, if messy for the reasons I
mentioned before. I think I can recommend the game, but I don't
think I would want to play it again.

Total time: 4:39
  • Video Games
  • ActRaiser
  • SNES
  • 1990

entry.title: Game: Final Fantasy 2 (US) (SNES, 1991) (2)
entry.content:
Game: Final Fantasy 2 (US) (SNES, 1991) (2)20130406
I started playing this game today and got up to the desert in 45
minutes. This game is so good.

The last time I played it, I used a fan translation of FFIV. I'm
noticing the difficulty level changes a lot this time. I intend
to go all the way through.

Something funny I noticed right away is that Cecil looks like a
mouse on the overworld... in particular the guy from Rocket
Knight adventures. His shadow is like a little tail.

The intro music as you leave Baron is amazing and gave me
goosebumps. So cool!

--

Later in the day, I got up to the Octomamm. I found that fight to
be really easy. I had about half MP on everyone and just blasted
him away.

Game 3:  2:00
Total time: 62:00

  • Final Fantasy 2 (US)
  • SNES
  • 1991

entry.title: Game: The Legend of the Mystical Ninja (SNES, 1991)
entry.content:
Game: The Legend of the Mystical Ninja (SNES, 1991)20130406
I played this for about an hour and got to the action sequence of
Zone 4.

In some ways, this game is really similar to Actraiser: it fuses
two different gameplay sequences together in a way that barely
connects them. In this, there's a bland side-scrolling mode and
then the town modes where you can do mini-games and buy things. I
haven't found anything worth buying, because it's so easy to lose
things like armor and you can't buy weapons.

The style and setting of the game is really quirky and cute. It's
not just because "Hey, Japan!" It seems strange even for Japan,
with lots of weird creatures... like the octopus boss and the
weird pink masked guys.

I can't decide if I want to play it more. It's very adorable and
well known, but it isn't that good. I wonder if maybe there's
something great further in? If I look online, it looks like I'm a
little less than half-way through.

--

I played for another twenty-ish minutes and couldn't make it
through Zone 4's boss. I decided it wasn't worth continuing.

Total time: 1:08
  • Video Games
  • The Legend of the Mystical Ninja
  • SNES
  • 1991

entry.title: Movie: The Switch, starring Jason Bateman (2010)
entry.content:
Movie: The Switch, starring Jason Bateman (2010)20130406
This was a cute movie and not as formulaic as we expected it would
be after reading the envelope. I think the best part was the cute
kid and all the awkward things that he did. Something else
interesting is that the main character is the man in the romantic
comedy, and not the woman.
  • Movies
  • 2010
